questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Why does the end user complain of poor wireless performance?

choices.B: The client is using 20 MHz channel width to connect.
choices.C: Non-802.11 traffic of 18 percent indicates poor AP placement.
choices.D: The client is connected to the secondary radio of the AP instead of the primary radio.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The picture is wrong, it's not channel 36 utilization, but channel 48.
The answer is A

Selected Answer: A
APs and wireless clients on the same channel who are also within range of each other form a single broadcast domain, similar to an Ethernet hub. All devices can hear each other's transmissions and if any two devices transmit at the same time, their radio signals will collide and become garbled resulting in data corruption or complete frame loss. If there is an excessive amount of collisions, data would never be transmitted successfully and the wireless network would be unusable.
Answer is correct A'. Got the same on the exam with the correct picture.

Selected Answer: A
Not channel 48 utilization, but channel 36 in the pic.
The answer is A

Selected Answer: B
I guess it's B
The answer is B

questions.question_text: What is the default frequency of SD-WAN probes sent between VPN peers in a Cisco Meraki MX SD-WAN deployment?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
In a Cisco Meraki MX SD-WAN deployment, the default frequency of SD-WAN probes sent between VPN peers is once per second. These probes are used to measure the performance metrics such as latency, jitter, and packet loss between the VPN peers, which helps in making dynamic path selection decisions to ensure optimal performance and reliability of the SD-WAN connections.

Answer: C
The performance probe is a small payload (approximately 100 bytes) of UDP data sent over all established VPN tunnels every 1 second. MX appliances track the rate of successful responses and the time that elapses before receiving a response. This data allows the MX to determine the packet loss, latency, and jitter over each VPN tunnel in order to make the necessary performance-based decisions.
Ref.: https://documentation.meraki.com/Architectures_and_Best_Practices/Cisco_Meraki_Best_Practice_Design/Best_Practice_Design_-_MX_Security_and_SD-WAN/Meraki_SD-WAN

Selected Answer: C
The answer is c
https://documentation.meraki.com/Architectures_and_Best_Practices/Cisco_Meraki_Best_Practice_Design/Best_Practice_Design_-_MX_Security_and_SD-WAN/Meraki_SD-WAN

C is the correct answer

Selected Answer: C
Answer: C
Selective Wipe
A selective wipe on managed clients will remove all managed apps and managed profiles installed via SM, without fully factory resetting the device, and prevent additional apps or profiles from being pushed down. This can secure network resources (WiFi access, Exchange emails) without relying on the device user to remove the SM agent from their device.

This feature is most typically utilized when a BYOD device user is no longer affiliated with the Organization, or as an intermediary step before fully wiping a lost or stolen device. For more information about this feature, please see our Cisco Meraki Blog post on the topic.
Ref.: https://documentation.meraki.com/SM/Monitoring_and_Reporting/Selective_Wipe_and_Device_Quarantine_in_Systems_Manager

C is right
https://documentation.meraki.com/SM/Monitoring_and_Reporting/Selective_Wipe_and_Device_Quarantine_in_Systems_Manager

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. What is the ratio of internet-bound flows that route via WAN 1 compared with WAN 2?
Which enrollment method must be used when containerization is required on BYOD Android devices managed by Systems Manager?

choices.B: Android Enterprise utilizing a Work Profile
choices.C: Android Business utilizing a BYOD Profile

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Correct: B

Work Profile or BYOD. In BYOD mode administrators only have control over work managed applications and settings. Systems Manager will containerize all corporate data and represent it using an orange badge icon. An administrator will have complete control over these applications, but have no visibility or control over personal applications on the device.
Device Owner mode. In Device Owner mode administrators have complete control of the device. This type of deployment is primarily used on institutionally owned devices and include special features such as kiosk mode. (Device Owner mode can be thought of as the "Supervised" state for those familiar with iOS.)
Ref.: https://documentation.meraki.com/SM/Deployment_Guides/Android_Enterprise_Deployment_Guide

Selected Answer: B
I agree with B

Selected Answer: B
B is correct
The correct answer should be B

B is the correct answer, 
https://documentation.meraki.com/SM/Device_Enrollment/Containerization_with_Systems_Manager
